newsitem.title: UK: Bradford & Bingley buys Mortgage Express.
newsitem.headline: Bradford & Bingley buys Mortgage Express.

text.p: Britain's Bradford & Bingley Building Society boosted its assets by 1.5 billion pounds ($2.4 billion) on Friday when it bought mortgage lender Mortgage Express for 64 million pounds from Lloyds TSB Group.
"This was the big one. We resolved that it was important to get," Bradford & Bingley chief executive Christopher Rodrigues told Reuters.
He left open the possibilty of further acquisitions, saying the society was interested "in one or two areas" but declined to be more specific.
"I don't think this will be the last one but equally we are not going to see a flurry," he said.

Specialist lender Mortgage Express, which will become a wholly owned subsidiary of the group, will increase Bradford & Bingley's assets to more than 18.5 billion pounds. The society will become Britain's second largest when the current round of conversions to publicly listed banks is over.

Lloyds TSB spokeswoman Geraldine Davies said the sale eliminated duplication with the high street bank's mortgage provider Cheltenham & Gloucester, adding it was in the best interests of shareholders and Mortgage Express customers and staff.
Lloyds TSB said the profit before tax of 50 million pounds on the sale would be included in its half year results ending June 30.

Mortgage Express is based in north London and has 300 employees and more than 26,000 customers. Bradford & Bingley said in the last three years the group had "successfully turned around the sizeable non-performing lending portfolio and has created a well run, profitable business".
Bradford & Bingley said the move represented a diversification for the society, which has trumpeted the benefits of its mutual status since a number of its competitors chose to become banks.

It was a sensible step forward for the society and did not represent a weakening of its commitment to mutuality, where the group is owned by its savers and borrowers rather than shareholders, it added.
Mortgage Express does not provide the same sort of home loans as the mainstream British mortgage providers, traditionally the building societies.
Instead it offers what are accepted to be more "risky" products such as buy-to-rent loans, mortgages for self-employed and contract workers, second home finance and negative equity loans.
It is a centralised lender, distributing its products through third parties and direct to the public. Bradford & Bingley has paid 4.2 percent of asset value for it, in line with estimates.
There were also some industry sources who suggested Mortgage Express would dilute the quality of Bradford & Bingley's mortgage book, making it more vulnerable to market downturns.
But Rodrigues dismissed any such suggestion.
"I have every confidence that this will not cause a deterioration in the society's performance," he said in an telephone interview.
"There is substantial value in the existing loan book and great potential for the specialist lending products Mortgage Express now sells," he added.
The acquisition also gave the building society the skills to securitise parts of the balance sheet, which would help it to fund the growth of Bradford & Bingley's existing business, he added.
This would mean greater freedom for Bradford & Bingley in managing its balance sheet, and was likely to lead to securitisation of some of its Mortgage Express assets during the year.
Securitisation is a process of ring-fencing assets such as loans and then raising capital on the strength of them.

Mortgage Express went through a difficult period in the early 1990s. It stopped taking on new business at the height of the housing recession in 1991, when it was losing money at a rate of a million pounds a week, but has since recovered.
"Over the past three years, the Mortgage Express team has successfully turned around the sizeable non-performing lending portfolio and has created a well-run profitable business," Rodrigues said.

"You must look at Mortgage Express as what it is today and not what it was five years ago," he said, adding that Bradford & Bingley had bought a business that was already properly provided for. ($ = 0.615 British Pounds)
